awd_titl_txt: Novel Methods for Radical and Electrophilic Amination
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports a project led by Professor Justin Lopchuk at the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center. He is developing new methods for organic synthesis.  This project focuses on the formation carbon-nitrogen bonds.  Many important chemicals, especially pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials, have carbon-nitrogen bonds.  The new methods emphasize reagents that have been overlooked in previous work. Of particular interest is the use nitrogen-containing precursors with unusual electron counts.  Another class of reagents features small rings containing one or two nitrogen atoms. In addition to the laboratory research, Professor Lopchuk is leading several efforts to broaden the impact of his work.  He is organizing workshops to facilitate collaborations and educating nonchemists about the value of organic and medicinal chemistry.  

Nitrogen-containing compounds are ubiquitous in nature and comprise the majority of small molecule pharmaceuticals as well many of those in development. Supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Justin Lopchuk at the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center is leading a program to invent new routes to carbon-nitrogen (C-N) bonds. Despite the considerable recent advances, both electrophilic amination and radical amination remain challenging, especially in the context of intermolecular reactions. The goal of this project is the design and synthesis of a series of strained bench-stable reagents for the required electrophilic or radical aminations. These reagents are used in a diverse array of reactions and give versatile intermediates. The goal is the rapid preparation of a wide range of high value nitrogen-containing compounds including amines, hydrazines, and heterocycles.  These components are relevant to medicinal chemistry, chemical biology, agrochemistry and materials science. The broader impacts of this work starts with the creation of a novel compound screening library for drug discovery. An interactive workshop on synthetic organic chemistry is being developed to facilitate communication among staff throughout the Moffitt Cancer Center and the University of South Florida.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this project are to use diazirines to react with a carbon radical, generated from a suitable chemical handle, to form a new carbon-nitrogen bond in the form of a diaziridine. Diaziridines are strained, three-membered heterocycles that serve as masked amines or hydrazines and can ultimately be converted to a wide variety of heterocycles useful for pharmaceutical, agrochemical, or materials applications.

Intellectual merit. During the funded period, we have demonstrated that diazirines, under iron-catalyzed or photo-mediated conditions, react with redox-active esters to form N-alkyl-substituted diaziridines. The reactions have a broad scope and good functional group tolerance. The redox-active esters, derived from carboxylic acids, may be primary, secondary, or tertiary, and the substrates may contain esters, alkenes/alkynes, alcohols, ketones, and alkyl halides. Late-stage functionalization examples included the modification of progesterone, mycophenolic acid, gemfibrozil, and atorvastatin. Mild conditions were developed for the selective conversion of the diaziridines to either amines or hydrazines as needed. Since the handling and purification of both alkyl amines and alkyl hydrazines is challenging, we enabled numerous one-pot and telescoped methods for the creation of many heterocycles, including pyrrole, pyrazole, imidazole, and pyridazinone. All our diazirine amination methods are amenable to fluorous phase synthesis by changing the trifluoromethyl group (CF3) on the diazirine to a perfluorinated tail (C8F17). This greatly simplifies purification by removing the need for flash chromatography and expediting the library synthesis of nitrogen-containing compounds. More recently we have found that carboxylic acids, instead of redox-active esters, may be used in the reaction with diazirines. This requires an acridinium photocatalyst and blue LEDs. In addition to maintaining many of the scope and features of the two previous reactions, this version includes the amination of benzylic substrates (such as naproxen and ibuprofen) as well as the late-stage functionalization of gibberellic acid. Expanded heterocycle syntheses include the regioselective preparation of both 1H- and 2H-indazoles as well as ciprofloxacin derivatives.

The further exploration of diazirine reactivity resulted in the discovery of a transition-metal catalyzed hydroamination of unactivated olefins. With the use of a cobalt salen catalyst, the reactions are regioselective, resulting in highly substituted diaziridines from readily available feedstock chemicals. Alcohols, amines, esters, aldehydes, and epoxides are all tolerated in the reaction. A variety of terpenes were successfully employed, providing a new way to aminate this abundant class of natural products. We demonstrated the utility of this reaction through the synthesis of mecamylamine, neramexane, and other clinical candidates in a regioselective fashion. Lastly, we developed a new route to doubly labeled 15N diazirine, affording a more economical entry into isotopically labeled amines, hydrazines, and heterocycles. 

Broader Impacts. Fundamentally, our research is focused on the design and development of new reactions for the synthesis of small molecules. Through the discoveries described above, we have advanced the field of radical and electrophilic amination, specifically for the synthesis of amines, hydrazines, and nitrogen-containing heterocycles. These compounds are directly useful, and thus have broader impacts, in drug discovery, agrochemistry, and materials science. Furthermore, this research has provided an excellent training ground in synthetic organic chemistry for undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows who have gone on to other positions in academia or industry.


Last Modified: 02/10/2024
Modified by: Justin M Lopchuk
